review.title: MRA - Proof of Concept of a Multilingual Report Annotator Web Application
review.abstract: MRA (Multilingual Report Annotator) is a web application that translates Radiology text and annotates it with RadLex terms. Its goal is to explore the solution of translating non-English Radiology reports as a way to solve the problem of most of the Text Mining tools being developed for English. In this brief paper we explain the language barrier problem and shortly describe the application. MRA can be found at

metadata.title: MRA - Proof of Concept of a Multilingual Report Annotator Web Application

sections.heading: Background
sections.text: Radiological reports describe the results of radiological procedures and have the potential to be a useful source of information (1) that can bring benefits to health systems around the world. Another advantage of radiological reports is that, even if written in free text, they are usually well structured. (3) Much work has been done on text mining biomedical texts, including health records (2), but although radiological reports are usually written in the radiologist's native language, text mining tools are mostly developed for English. (3) An information extraction system for English reports has been created that depends on RadLex (4), a radiology terminology lexicon that is freely available in English.

sections.heading: Description
sections.text: The flow of the application goes like this: the user loads a text file with radiology text into the application (Figure 1), and if the text is available in a non-English language, it is sent to Unbabel's translation services 1, which combine human translation with machine translation. Currently, the application supports five languages beyond English, which are supported by the Unbabel API. In this prototype, only machine translation is used for demonstration purposes. In a real scenario, human translation could also be used for more reliable results. So, the text is sent to the translation and after a while (about 2 minutes to simulate a real human and machine translation) the translation is finished. Afterwards, the translated text is sent to BioPortal2 annotation services. Afterwards, it is possible to examine the annotations in the translated text and after a while (about 2 minutes to simulate a real human and machine translation) find the annotation of the text in the translated text (the annotation of the text was inspired by a similar project name).

sections.heading: 1 https://unbabel.com/
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: The idea is that this application can be used to launch other, more useful applications. It can also be shown to clinical institutes to pique their interest in what can be done when you integrate translation into medical practice.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: Thanks to Miguel Rodrigues and André Lamúrias for suggestions.
